question: I'm in a car wash.
answer: A car wash! Wow, I've never talked to you when you've been in a car wash. Make sure you've got the windows closed. Remember that time we were having the car washed and I started playing with the automatic window? How old was I, Daddy? Five or six? I got absolutely soaked, remember?

question: Why are you calling me, Zoe?
answer: Why am I calling you? You're my father. I'm not supposed to call you? What's the matter with wanting to talk to you, Daddy?

question: Nothing's wrong with trying to talk to me, Zoe.
The problem is I have no idea who I'm talking to right now.
answer: 'Cause you think I'm stoned, Daddy? 'Cause you think I've got a needle stuck in my arm? Is that what you're thinking, Daddy? Are you wondering if I scored, Daddy, and I'm calling you for money? That I'm begging? God, I don't fucking believe it!

question: Need a hand?
answer: Sure, it you could find a towel in this bag. I know my wife packed one in there...

question: You always think you're prepared for these things.
How old is she?
Is this it?
Here we go.
That was great.
You're going to blow everyone away.
Of course.
answer: You don't sound like one hundred percent absolutely sure.

question: I am. Really. It was awesome.
Hard to say. I might have...some business here.
No.
Kyle Lambston's a drunk. Nobody likes him. He's a nasty piece of work.
Been drinking since high school. Fucked himself up. Used to be smart enough.
Probably half a dozen traffic convictions. Drunk driving. Lost his licence. That's why he don't work no more. Can't get off that shitty dump they live on. What little money comes in goes to booze.
Don't know. Food banks, welfare, church charity. They scrape by.
What about Doreen?
answer: She...she was a friend of mine.

question: When?
answer: At school. She fell for Kyle just before we graduated. Got pregnant, and...went to live in a trailer up on a woodlot Kyle's dad used to own. Kyle started spending more and more time at the Spread Eagle...

question: That's the local bar?
answer: ...coming home drunk and I guess feeling trapped by his life and blaming her for that...and...

question: There's the Prescots...
answer: That sonofabitch owes thousands to the bank and half the businesses in town. He's about to lose his house and car.

question: But Charlene...
answer: Charlene's over at the Spread Eagle every other night. Sleeps with whatever she can get her hands on. She'll go down for a pat on the head and a fistful of peanuts. Don't even think of the Bilodeaus or the Atwaters. They're all inbred.

question: The Ottos.
Wanda and Hartley. They lost Bear. He was their adopted son. A beautiful boy. Indian.
Yes.
answer: That's good. Judges like adopted Indian boys. Tell me more about the Ottos.

question: They're smart. Been to college. They moved here from the city about a dozen years ago.
Crafts.
You can have mine. Yes, we do know each other. I'm Alison Jones.
Ally. That was my nickname.
How are you?
answer: I'm just fine, Ally. What about you?

question: I'm fine. Still working with my father.
answer: And what does he do again?

question: He used to work with you. Until you found out he was having an affair with your wife.
How is Mrs. Stephens?
I'd heard that. But she's well?
Good morning, Wanda. Hi, Hartley.
answer: Hi, Dolores. What do you think?

question: Well, it's certainly what you'd call interesting.
I didn't say that.
answer: I could wrap it up. Protect the other kids.

question: I'll just strap it on the roof.
Oh, it's bizarre alright. C'mon Bear. Let's get you out of here.
Dolores. No one calls me 'Mrs. Driscoll'.
answer: What do you mean by that, Dolores?

question: About the Ottos?
answer: Yes. What do you mean by 'hippies'?

question: I mean, the way they look. Their hair and clothing...
answer: Do they have any reputation for drugs?

question: No, nothing like that. The Ottos are what I'd call model citizens. They're regular at town meetings. They give their opinions in a respectful way. They always help out at various fund-raising bazaars in town , though they aren't church goers.
So Billy was driving behind the bus at the time of the accident?
answer: Billy loved to see his kids in the bus. They always sat in the back, so they could wave to each other. It comforted him.

question: From what?
Did he have any particular problems that you knew of? Financial pressures...run-ins with the law...
answer: No, nothing like that. Billy's wife, Lydia, died of cancer a few years ago. He took over raising the children by himself. It was obvious how much he missed Lydia.

question: You talked about it?
answer: No. I saw it on his face.

question: Hi...Can you talk? I'm on my way to work...I'm waving at them now...What's that noise?
answer: Wendell's working on the roof. He thinks he's fixing a leak. As far as I'm concerned he's just punching in a few new holes.

question: Nicole's coming over to look after the kids tonight. She'll be there around six.
She said she's got to be home by nine.
answer: Can't you make it later? I guess.

question: I'm glad to hear that Zoe's okay.
Not really. The last time I saw her was at that clinic. That was a long time ago.
Which one?
I don't remember the name. It was near a beach.
answer: Sunnyridge. That was a long time

question: So there were others?
answer: Other clinics? Oh sure. Clinics, half-way houses, treatment centers, detox units...

question: Then...when did she get better?
But you said...
answer: That's where I'm going. To see her.

question: She's in trouble?
answer: Yes. Do you find there's something strange about this meat?

question: Yes. Do you find there's something strange about this meat?
I'm afraid this meat is overdone.
answer: I'm sorry about that, Mr. Stephens. Would you like to try the fish?

question: What is it?
Do you have a cold plate?
Is there shrimp on it?
If you could pick the shrimp off, as well as anything that touches the shrimp...
answer: I'm not sure if that will leave much on the plate.

question: Well, let's see what we get. If you could excuse me for a moment. Mrs. Otto, my name is Mitchell Stephens. The Walkers told me you might be willing to talk to me. I'm sorry for coming over unannounced like this, Mrs. Otto, but the Walkers said you would understand. I know it's an awful time, but it's important that we talk.
I'm a lawyer.
Please, let me explain. I'll only take a moment of your time.
Please.
answer: We have a guest. What did you say your name was? The Walkers sent him by.

question: A cup of tea would be nice. Would it be alright if I sit down for a few minutes, Mrs. Otto? I want to talk to you. The Walkers spoke very highly of you.
Yes.
answer: Their child died, and they got a lawyer.

question: It should be said that my task is to represent the Walkers only in their anger. Not their grief.
answer: Who did they get for that?

question: You are angry, aren't you, Mrs. Otto? That's why I'm here. To give your anger a voice. To be your

It's my belief that Dolores was doing exactly what she'd been doing for years. Besides, the school board's insurance on Dolores is minimal. A few million at the very most. The really deep pockets are to be found in the town, or in the company that made the bus.
answer: You think someone else caused the accident?

question: Mrs. Otto, there is no such thing as an accident. The word doesn't mean anything to me. As far as I'm concerned, somebody somewhere made a decision to cut a corner. Some corrupt agency or corporation accounted the cost variance between a ten-cent bolt and a million dollar out-of-court settlement. They decided to sacrifice a few lives for the difference. That's what's done, Mrs. Otto. I've seen it happen so many times before. How long has Dolores been driving that bus, Mr. Otto? How many times has she steered clear of danger? What went wrong that morning? Someone calculated ahead of time what it would cost to sacrifice safety. It's the darkest, most cynical thing to imagine, but it's
answer: So you're just the thing we need.

question: Excuse me?
answer: Isn't that what you want us to believe? That we're completely defenseless? That you know what's best?

question: Listen to me, Mrs Otto. Listen very carefully. I do know what's best. Who is responsible for this tragedy. Then, in your name and the Walkers' name and the name of whoever decides to join us, I shall sue. I shall sue for negligence until they bleed.
answer: I want that person to go to jail. For the rest of his life. I want him to die there. I don't want his money.

question: It's unlikely that anyone will go to prison, Mrs. Otto. But he or his company will pay in other ways. And we must make them pay. Not for the No. A little sugar though. I'll...take it straight.

No. If you agree to have me represent you in this suit, I will require no payment until after the case is won, when I will require one third of the awarded amount. If there is no award made, then my services will cost you nothing. It's a standard agreement.
answer: Do you have this agreement with you?

question: Hi, Nicole.
answer: Hi, Mr. Ansel. Hi, Jessica, Mason...

question: They just finished supper.
I'll be back around nine.
Have you been waiting long?
Billy, do you have to smoke? Wendell can smell if someone's been smoking.
answer: What's all this? Does this mean I can't take a shower?

question: No. It should be dry by now.
The Pied Piper of Hamelin. By famous Hanover city; The river Weser, deep and wide, Washes its wall on the southern side; A pleasanter spot you never spied; But, when begins my ditty...
It's like a song.

Rats! They fought the dogs and killed the cats, And bit the babies in the cradles, And ate the cheeses out of vats. And licked the soup from the cook's own ladles, Split open the kegs of salted sprats, Made nests inside men's Sunday hats, And even spoiled the women's chats, By drowning their speaking With shrieking and squeaking In fifty different sharps and flats...
Yes.
answer: Can I sit beside you on the bus tomorrow?

question: Don't you usually like to sit at the back? To wave at your Dad?
answer: I want to sit beside you tomorrow.

question: Okay.
What, Mason? That's right.
answer: Well, if he knew magic - if he could get the kids into the mountain - why couldn't he use his pipe to make the people pay him for getting rid of the rats?

question: Because...he wanted to them to be punished.
Yes.
No. Not mean. Just...very angry.
Should I keep reading?
What are you thinking?
answer: Tomorrow I'm going to put Sean on the bus. He won't want to go. He never does. He'll cry and want to hold on to me.

question: That's because he misses you.
It's natural.
Well, maybe that's because they know I'm going to follow them. Behind the bus.
answer: They can look forward to that.

question: Sure.
answer: Just like we look forward to this. You're leaving.

question: I better get back.
Good night.
Yeah.
Why?
Nicole, I'm just going to pack all this stuff and give it to the church for charity. Don't feel bad. Unless you feel strange about wearing it.
answer: No. I mean, I remember Mrs. Ansel wearing some of this stuff, but...I don't feel funny about that. I really liked her.

question: And she really liked you. She would've given you all this if she'd outgrown it, or...
I'm not sure.
What took so long?
What's that?
Does it fit?
answer: Once more he stept into the street, And to his lips again Laid his long pipe of smooth straight cane; And ere he blew three notes such sweet soft notes as yet musician's cunning Never gave the enraptured air - There was a rustling, seemed like a bustling Of merry crowds justling at pitching and hustling, Small feet were pattering, wooden shoes clattering, When, lo, as they reached the mountain-side, A wondrous portal opened wide, As if a cavern was suddenly hollowed; And the Piper advanced and the children followed, And when all were in to the very last, The door in the mountain-side shut fast... Did I say, all? No! One was lame, And could not dance the whole of the way; And in after years, if you would blame His sadness, he was used to say,- 'It's dull in the town since my Everything was strange and new.

question: That's the way I thought of them sometimes.
Yes. Like I was putting them into my big basket. Clearing the hillside of its children. Abbott and I used to do a lot of that in the spring.
Yes. The old-fashioned way.
A strange little fellow, but you couldn't help liking him. He was close to ten but seemed more like a frightened five or six.
What do you mean?
answer: You mentioned that he had a learning disability.

question: That's right.
answer: Did his parents attend to that?

question: What do you mean?
answer: Did they give him special care?

question: Every time I get on one of these flights to rescue Zoe, I remember the summer we almost lost her. She was three years old. It happened in the morning, at this cottage we used to rent. We were all sleeping together in bed. It was a wonderful time in our lives. We still thought we had a future together, the three of us. Did you ever visit the cottage?
I woke to the sound of Zoe's breathing. It was laboured. I looked over and noticed she was sweating and all swollen. I grabbed her, rushed to the kitchen, and splashed water on her face.
I knew you'd be here. Are you going to the funeral?
answer: I stopped by the station a while ago. I stared at the bus. I could almost hear the kids inside. There was a lawyer there. He told me he'd gotten you signed up. Is that true?

question: Something made this happen, Billy. Mr. Stephens is going to find out what it was. Mr. Stephens says that someone didn't put a right bolt in the bus...
answer: Risa, I serviced that bus. At the garage. There's nothing wrong with it.

question: ...or that the guardrail wasn't strong enough.
I have to.
Because I have to.
Is it true that you gave Nicole one of Lydia's dresses? That she was wearing it when the bus crashed?
Why did you do that, Billy?
answer: You think that caused the accident, Risa? That it brought bad luck? Christ, it sounds to me you're looking for a witch doctor, not a lawyer. Or maybe they're the same thing. You know what I'm going to miss? More than making love? It's the nights you couldn't get away from Wendell. It's the nights I'd sit in that chair for an hour. Smoking cigarettes and remembering my life before...

question: You think that caused the accident, Risa? That it brought bad luck? Christ, it sounds to me you're looking for a witch doctor, not a lawyer. Or maybe they're the same thing. You know what I'm going to miss? More than making love? It's the nights you couldn't get away from Wendell. It's the nights I'd sit in that chair for an hour. Smoking cigarettes and remembering my life before...
answer: I'm here about your children, Mr. Ansel. My name is...

question: Mister, I don't want to know your name.
No you don't.
Not unless you can raise the dead.
answer: Here. You may change your mind.

question: Mr. Mitchell Stephens, Esquire, would you be likely to sue me if I was to beat you right now? Beat you so bad that you pissed blood and couldn't walk for a month. Because that's what I'm about to do.
answer: No, Mr. Ansel. I wouldn't sue you.

question: Leave us alone, Stephens. Leave the people of this town alone. You can't help.
answer: You can help each other. Several people have agreed to let me represent them in a negligence suit. Your case as an individual will be stronger if I'm allowed to represent you together as a group.

question: Case?
answer: The Walkers have agreed. The Ottos. Nicole Burnell's parents. It's important to initiate proceedings right away. Things get covered up. People lie. That's why we have to begin our investigation quickly. Before the evidence disappears. That's why I'm out here tonight.

question: I know Risa and Wendell Walker. They wouldn't hire a goddamned lawyer. And the Ottos wouldn't deal
answer: You're angry, Mr. Ansel. You owe it to yourself to feel that way. All I'm saying is let me direct your rage. That's my daughter. Or it may be the police to tell me that they've found her dead. She's a drug addict.

question: Why are you telling me this?
answer: I'm telling you this because... we've all lost our children, Mr. Ansel. They're dead to us. They kill each other in the streets. They wander comatose in shopping malls. They're paralyzed in front of televisions. Something terrible has happened that's taken our children away. It's too late. They're gone.

question: I have a question for you, Mr. Stephens.

I told you that I was doing fifty miles an hour when the accident happened. That's how I remembered it. But the truth is, I might have been doing sixty. Or sixty five. And if that's true, that I was over the limit when the bus went over, what would happen then?
Because I'd be to blame, right?
answer: Billy Ansel will insist that you were driving fifty-one miles an hour. Just like you've done every morning for the past fifteen years.

question: He knows that? Billy?
Billy said that? You've talked to Billy?
And Billy told you that he'll tell that to...
answer: Mrs. Driscoll, if Billy Ansel does not volunteer to say so in court, I will subpoena him and oblige him to testify to that effect. But in order to do that, you must let me bring a suit in your name It's clear to me and other people that you have suffered significantly from this event.

question: What other people?
Who's been talking to you about what I'm feeling? Who should care about what I'm feeling?
answer: Dolores, people have to know that you've suffered too. And they won't understand until you let me clear your name - your good name - once and for all. Will you let me do that? Will you let me do my duty?

question: You heard what Abbott said?
Anything you didn't understand?
answer: There might have been a word or two that slipped by. Maybe you could clarify it for me, just to be absolutely sure.

question: Abbott said that the true jury of a person's peers is the people of her town. Only they, the people who have known her all her life, and not twelve strangers, can decide her guilt or innocence. And if I have committed a crime, then it's a crime against them, so they are the ones who must decide my punishment.
answer: That's what he said, is it?

question: It's an incredible relief to be leaving the hospital. I'm so sick of looking at my doctor, listening to Frankenstein ask me stupid questions about what I was feeling... He thought it was cute when I called him Frankenstein. It wasn't. I feel like his monster.
What happened to summer?
And winter?
answer: Well, winter's far behind us now.

question: How was it?
answer: We had a terrible winter last year, didn't we, Sam?

question: Good thing I was in Florida.
answer: How do you like it, Nicole?

question: The ramp?
Very slick.
It's okay.
answer: And I had to widen a few doors. You'll see. What do you think?

question: The door needs a lock.
answer: Sure. I'll fix it right away.

question: So do you like your new room?
Your Dad spent all his spare time in here. He wanted to make it absolutely perfect.
answer: I feel like a princess. Is this mine?

question: Yes. It's a present.
No. From Mr. Stephens. That was him on the phone just now. He was calling to see how you were.
Who's Mr. Stephens?
answer: He's a lawyer. He's our lawyer.

question: You and Mom have a lawyer?
answer: Well, yes. He's your lawyer too.

question: You're going to need special care for a long time to come. It's not going to be easy. Not for you, not for any of us. Because we love you so much. And it's going to cost money. More than we can imagine.
answer: What about insurance? Doesn't insurance pay for these things?

question: Partly. But there's a lot the insurance doesn't cover. That's one of the reasons we have a lawyer. To make sure the insurance gets paid and to help us look after the rest.

Well, Mr. Stephens is representing several families. The Ottos, the Walkers, us, and I think a couple more. Mr. Stephens is suing the town for negligence. He's sure that the accident could have been avoided if they had done their jobs right. He's a very smart man.
answer: That's the first thing I heard about you. That you were a smart man. You're good at that. Good at getting people to believe you could do something for them. Something they could never do for themselves.

question: They're dead to us. Yes, I'll accept the charges.
Yes.
answer: I'm calling because I've got some news for you, Daddy. Some big news.

question: News?
Yes. Give me your news, Zoe.
answer: You always think you know what I'm going to say, don't you? You always think you're two steps ahead of me. The lawyer.

question: Tell me your news, Zoe.
answer: Okay. I went to sell blood yesterday. That's how it is. I'm in this fucking city where my father is a hot shit lawyer, and I'm selling my blood.

question: That's not news, Zoe.
answer: No. But this is. They wouldn't take my blood. Do you know what that means, Daddy? Does it register?

question: Yes.
Yes.
What do you want me to do, Zoe? I'll do whatever you want.
What for?
answer: You can't ask me that! Not anymore! You asked me what I wanted. Not what I wanted it for. I want money.

question: Do you have the blood test?
answer: You don't believe me? You don't fucking believe me?

question: Of...course I do. I just thought...I could get you another
answer: I like it when you don't believe me, Daddy. It's better you don't believe me but have to act like you do. I can hear you breathing, Daddy.

question: Yes. I can hear you breathing too.
It's the truth.
answer: It is the truth. It would be strange if you didn't feel that way.

question: What do you want me to do for you, Mr. Stephens?
answer: They work for the people we're trying to sue. Their job is to try to minimize damages. Our job, Nicole, is to try to maximize them. You have to think of it that way. As people doing their jobs. No good guys or bad guys. Just our side and their side.

question: I won't lie.
answer: I don't want you to lie.

question: The truth is that it was an accident, and no one's to blame.
answer: There's no such thing as an accident, Nicole. Not in a situation like this.

question: You seem very sure about that.
No matter what I'm asked, I'll tell the truth.
answer: That's fine. I want you to be absolutely truthful. And I'll be right there to advise and help you. And there'll be a court stenographer there to make a record of it, and

question: Dolores.
answer: Yes. Dolores...and even your mom and dad. But I'll make sure you go last.

question: Why?
answer: So you can keep on getting well before you have to go and do this. It's not going to be easy, Nicole. Do you understand that?

question: He never took his eyes off his mother, even as he moved to sit beside Nicole. He looked frightened.

I don't know. But it was weird in terms of what happened next. Sean was still watching his mother. I shut the door with one hand, and released the brake with the other, and waited for a second for Risa to cross in front of the bus. There was a sixteen wheeler behind me, and I heard his air brakes hiss as the driver chunked into gear. I looked into the side view mirror, and saw him move into line behind me. Then suddenly Sean shrieked...
That was Billy Ansel on the phone. He wants to come over to talk to us.
No.
answer: Was he drinking? Could you tell?

question: So what brings you out tonight?
answer: Well, Sam, I might as well tell you the truth. It's this lawsuit you've gotten yourself all involved with. I want you to drop the damned thing.

question: I don't see how that concerns you, Billy.
Well, I don't know why it should. There's a whole lot of people in town involved with lawsuits. We're hardly unique here, Billy. I mean, I can understand how you feel.
Well, it being so depressing and all. But it's reality. You can't just turn this off because you happen to think it's a bad idea.
Because it's what we have to do.
answer: Well I don't want a damned thing to do with it.

question: Okay, fine. So...stay out of it.
answer: I've tried to stay out of it. But it turns out that's not so easy, Sam. You've gone and got yourself this lawyer. Mitchell Stephens. You and Risa and Wendell and the Ottos.

question: So? I mean, lot's of folks have got lawyers.
answer: But yours is the one who's going to subpoena me, Sam. Force me to testify in court. He came by the garage this afternoon. Gave me this piece of paper.

question: Because I was driving behind the bus, Mary. Because I saw it. I saw it happen... If that bastard does subpoena me, if he forces me to go over this again, then all those other lawyers will line up behind him and try and do the same thing.
answer: That won't happen, Billy. Mitch Stephens' case is small, compared to some of those other guys. The way he told me, all he needs is for you to say what you saw that day, driving behind the bus. I know it's a painful thing to do, but it'll only take a few minutes of your time. That'll be the end of it.

question: That's wrong, Sam. You know that. We'll be tangled up in this thing for the next five years. This is never going to go away...
If you two dropped the case, then the others would come to their senses and follow. You're good sensible parents, you and Mary. People respect you.
answer: No, Billy. We can't drop the lawsuit. You know how much we need the money.

question: Why? You got money from Dolores' insurance with the school board. We all did.
answer: It's not enough. For hospital bills. For Nicole.

question: I'll help pay for Nicole, if that's what you're really talking about. I'll even give you the money I got for my kids. That's what we used to do, remember? Help each other. This was a community.
I used to like it here. I used to care about what happened. Now I think I'll sell my house and move the fuck away.
The children. How is Nicole? Is she around?
Are you sleeping?
Nicole, tomorrow Mr. Stephens wants you to make your deposition at the courthouse. I thought I'd take you over.
You seem...I don't know...well, distant, I guess. Hard to talk to. What do you mean?
answer: I mean I'm a wheelchair girl now. It's hard to pretend I'm a beautiful rock star. Not like you used to tell me. Remember, Daddy? All the people that were going to discover me? Where are they now? He couldn't look at me. But I looked at him. Right at him. His secret was mine now. We used to share it. But not anymore. Now, I owned it completely.

question: Well, okay. I'll take you about nine-thirty in the morning. That's okay with you?
answer: Great. Before, everything had been so confusing. I never knew who was to blame. But now I know. He's just a thief, a sneaky thief who had robbed his daughter. Robbed me of...whatever it was that my sister still had and I didn't. And then the accident robbed me of my body.

question: Now on that morning, did there come a time, Nicole, when you left your parents' house?
What time in the morning was this?
Was anyone waiting for the bus with you?
answer: No. I was alone. My sister Jenny was sick and stayed home that day.

question: Was there anything unusual about the driver, Dolores Driscoll, or the bus that particular morning?
answer: Like what? I mean, I don't remember a lot.

question: Was the bus on time?
And where did you sit that morning?
answer: My usual place. On the right side. The first seat.

question: And according to your recollection, there was nothing unusual about the drive that morning?
answer: Until the accident? No. Yes, there was. It was when Sean Walker got on. He was crying and didn't want to leave his mother. Mason Ansel was sitting beside me. I asked him to move, so I could quiet Sean down. When the bus started up, a car came around

question: And was this incident caused in any way by anything the driver of the bus did?
answer: No, she hadn't even started to move the bus. It was the car's fault.

question: No.
answer: Did there come a time when all the children had been picked up?

question: Yes.
I will offer that report. Well, then, now that your memory seems to be clearing, can you tell us what else you observed at that time?
Yes.
Why were you scared? This is before the accident, Nicole. Do you understand what I'm asking?
Why were you scared?
Mrs. Driscoll was driving too fast? What made you think that, Nicole?
answer: The speedometer. And it was downhill there.

question: You could see the speedometer?
answer: Yes. I looked. I remember clearly now. It seemed we were going too fast down the hill. I was scared.

question: How fast would you say Mrs. Driscoll was going? To the best of your recollection?
Seventy-two miles an hour? You're sure of this?
You believe that the bus driven by Mrs. Driscoll was going at seventy- two miles an hour at this time?
answer: I told you I was positive. The speedometer was large and easy to see from where I was.

question: You saw the speedometer?
Did you say anything to Mrs. Driscoll?
Why not?
answer: I was scared. And there wasn't time.

question: There wasn't time?
answer: No. Because the bus went off the road. And crashed.

question: You remember this?
answer: Yes. I do now. Now that I'm telling it.

question: What do you remember about the accident?
answer: I remember the bus swerved, it just suddenly swerved to the right, and it hit the guardrail and the snowbank on the side of the road, and then it went over the embankment there, and everyone was screaming and everything. And that's all. I guess I was unconscious after that. That's all. Then I was in the hospital.

question: Do you have any questions, Mr. Stephens?
answer: Daddy was leaning forward in his chair, his mouth half open, as if he wanted to say something. Like what, Daddy? Like 'What about my money?'

question: Well, it was nice meeting you again, Mr. Stephens.
answer: Mitchell. It was nice to see you again, Ally.

question: Alison.
Say hi to Zoe.
I hope she gets better.
